content.description:
There are two fun extensions to all of the Abinadi lines.

Starting on

Abinadi.5's

initial holds, traverse right using the jug rail and finish up

Abinadi.2

or

Abinadi.3

or

Abinadi.4

.

Or... starting just below

Abinadi.5's

initial holds, traverse right only using the slopers and finish up on

2

or

3

or

4

.

The same can be done, going left on

Abinadi.5

.

There are variations all over the place!

This is a great aesthetic line going up the overhanging arete.

Start on the nose jugs.  Do a big left to a crimp pinch on the arete.  Go right to a great crimp on the face.  Finish by going straight up the arete on sloping good holds.
content.protection: Multiple pads are suggested.  It is not a fun landing.
content.location: This is the furthest left line on the block.

content.description: Start in the middle of the undercut block on jugs.  High heel and go left to the tiny crimp in the middle of the face (a tooth of the crimp broke last session, so make sure those pads and spotters are in place). Then finish with the crimp rail at the lip and top out.

Utilize that triangle crimp in the dihedral. Start in the jug rail, go right or left hand to the crimp and then pull up to the big crack or big crimps at the lip (be careful, the right side looks like it'll break soon).

Match on jugs in the crack.  Do a big cross with the left hand to the full-pad edge on the face.  Go right to a decent sloper, then finish on

Abinadi.1

with a little tension move.

Another variation is to go left to the triangle crimp in the dihedral and then right gaston to the full-pad edge - top out straight from there.

This is the first problem you come to as you as you come to Abinadi from Guano.

Start on the big horn on the edge of the block and go up solid holds.

Also, this is the downclimb for the rest of the problems, unless you want to use the tree behind the boulder.
content.location: This is the furthest right line on the wall.
